Graphical abstract Pictorial presentation of surface catalyzed oxidation of benzene to phenol in presence of CuO_AARM catalytic material following one-step environmentally benign conversion process. Phenol is a key intermediate in chemical industry. The present research work reports facile synthesis of a new copper supported activated red mud as a heterogeneous catalyst for oxidative conversion of benzene to phenol. The process is simple and efficient for one pot hydroxylation reaction using H2O2 as an oxidant. The catalyst was characterized using FTIR, XRD, TEM, XPS and BET surface area analyzer. Catalyst reducible properties were studied using H2-TPR technique. The one-pot hydroxylation reaction, carried out at 75 °C under optimum reaction conditions in presence of catalytic material, shows conversion of benzene to phenol with 84.5 % and 87.1 % selectivity and conversion efficiency, respectively. The proposed mechanism emphasizes upon cooperative effect of residual and embedded metal ions in solid catalyst matrix as the contributing factor for efficient conversion and selectivity. The reusable properties of the material, tested up to 5th consecutive cycles of batch operation, indicate retention of selectivity (83.9 %) as well as conversion efficiency (86.7 %), suitable for future commercial development adhering to the principle of green chemistry. Keywords Catalyst Heterogeneous Hydroxylation Phenol Red-mud 1 Introduction The fundamental understanding of structural and chemical factors to study specific catalyst performance is important in view of number of variable factors such as catalytic activity, selectivity and durability. Development of new catalysts and catalytic technologies to transform benzene into phenol is currently attracting genuine scientific interest among researchers all over the world. The reason is attributed to the fact that phenol is a key intermediate in chemical industry for diverse production of number of key products/chemicals/intermediates such as resins, fungicides, pesticides, preservatives, pharmaceuticals, caprolactam and adipic acid [1]. At present, production of phenol accounts for 10 million metric tons [2]. Phenol is commercially synthesized from benzene following three steps cumene process, where compression of benzene and propylene is carried out at 30 bar pressure and at 250 °C temperature in presence of phosphoric acid catalyst [3]. The reaction also involves formation of cumene–hydroperoxide as intermediate and monitoring of requisite parameters to avoid any kind of industrial hazards. The conversion of benzene to phenol also regarded as an energy intensive process [3,4]. The low selectivity of phenol also resulted in less yield of phenol with generation of equivalent molar quantity of acetone as a side product indicating that the reaction suffers from lower atomic efficiency. Direct hydroxylation of benzene (HoB) to form phenol requires introduction of hydroxyl group in the benzene moiety and the conversion process is regarded as one of the most difficult task to achieve technically. In this context increasing global demand of phenol urgently requires a suitable alternative material/method/technology that can facilitate one-step hydroxylation of benzene. Development of alternative pathway can be helpful in reducing the need of currently adopted 3-step process with quantitative reduction of hazardous intermediates and chemicals. Use of heterogeneous catalyst in hydroxylation of benzene is advantageous due to ease of separation/recovery of solid catalytic material from the process. In addition, regeneration and reusability of catalyst make the process more environmentally acceptable in view of generation of less amount of hazardous waste leading to greener pathway and lesser pollution [5–12]. It is to be noted that the stability of benzene and high reactivity of phenol are two key factors which makes the conversion of benzene to phenol more challenging one. Among various explored catalytic materials, carbon based materials are widely explored because of low cost factor, but deactivation of carbon based catalytic materials happens quickly due to formation of coke on the material surface [1]. As an alternative, use of various noble metals in HoB has also been explored with limited success [9,6–12]. During hydroxylation process noble metal often produces over-oxidized products due to decomposition of oxidants which can be attributed to ease of electronic substitution of available hydrogen atoms. The electronic effect of phenoxide ion favors formation of other products such as catechol, benzoquinone, hydroquinone, etc. However, noble metals’ scarcity of availability and material rising cost contribute to its’ limited developments in catalytic chemistry. Commercial importance of use of transition metals in synthetic chemistry and chemical industries are well established. In this context, literature studies shows that use of transition metal oxides in hydroxylation of benzene is relatively less explored [9–11]. Transition metal oxides can be prepared with desired surface area, pore size and attached functionality by following appropriate protocol/reaction conditions along with variation of precursor materials. The prepared metal oxides are relatively thermally stable with longer shelf–life. Transition metal oxides are well known for their role in activation of less reactive aromatic CH bond. In addition, variable oxidation states and appreciable bond strength [9] of transition metal oxides provides unique characteristics for designing the materials for new catalytic applications including hydroxylation of benzene [6–12]. Mixed metal oxides has already been reported as good catalysts for hydroxylation benzene [6,7]. A recently published report shows that 44 % conversion of benzene with 91 % selectivity of phenol can be achieved using Cu–Fe mixed oxide in the reaction medium [10]. The enhanced activity of the catalyst was attributed to structural phases and redox modification resulting from interface between Cu and Fe metal. Interestingly, use of co-catalyst pyrazine-2-carboxylic acid (PCA) along with transition metal/metal oxide found to enhance selectivity of phenol to 95 %; however, with increasing cost factor of unit operation process [12]. VOPO4·2H2O (encapsulated in graphene oxide) is also a good catalyst used for hydroxylation of benzene with almost 100 % selectivity and 33 % conversion rate over phenol [2]. Performance of nano-particles in oxidation/reduction reactions in a heterogeneous catalysis shows intrinsic correlation between surface coordinated sites and associated electronic factors [13]. Transition metals such as Fe and Cu (both bulk and nano form) shows good catalytic activities [13]. Nano-sized material show more activity and selectivity due to availability of good surface area as well as quantum confinement effects. The impregnation of nano-sized materials over a suitable support/porous support often demonstrates better catalytic activity and selectivity [14–17]. Therefore, it is evident that use of porous material support could be able to provide appropriate outer surface areas/channels for the impregnation of nano-materials, thus facilitating prevention of sintering by spatial separation of nano-particles [17]. In general, porous support material, basically a three dimensional structure, can be designed to act as an aggregate-resistant system in presence of impregnated nano materials over the surface. As an example, combination of nano-sized materials such as copper/copper oxides and iron over a porous material support can be used for controlled decomposition of hydrogen peroxide [10,11,13]. Hydrogen peroxide is often used an oxidant in hydroxylation of benzene in addition to N2O, O2, O2/N2 [13–21]. Catalytic reactions could happen over active sites of metals/supported metals for binding with oxygen–water molecules and facilitating their selective release/participation in hydroxylation reactions [5–10]. Copper could also promote enhancement of oxygen vacancies over metal surface that provide good selectivity in a catalytic reaction [11,13,15]. Oxidants such as oxygen (O2) and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) are mostly considered for their environmental as well as economic aspects [22–24]. H2O2 is commonly used in liquid phase for carrying out hydroxylation of benzene. Hydrogen peroxide decomposes to H2O as a side product. However, use of H2O2 often leads to very little conversion of benzene to phenol. On the other hand, use of iron (Fe), as an element, shows reaction with H2O2 in acidic medium to produce H2O and O2 and the reaction leads to formation of hydroxyl free radicals [4,10]. Similarly, copper based catalysts also find wide applications in various hydrogenation and oxidation reactions [15]. In view of the above mentioned references and discussions, the present research work is focused on finding strategy for use of red mud as a suitable support material for selective hydroxylation of benzene to phenol. Red mud is produced in large quantities from alumina industries (Bayer’s process). It is documented that approximately 2 MT of red mud is generated for 1 MT of alumina (Al2O3) production amounting to global production of nearly 170 million MT of red mud. So efficient disposal and utilization of red mud in chemical processes including catalyst development is a challenge as well as opportunity for future industrial research [25–33]. Discharge of red mud to water/soil often increases the pH to high alkaline condition, therefore, affecting aquatic ecosystem as well as fertility of the soil. Currently, red mud is used in production of construction materials (e.g. clinker in Portland cement), casting material, ceramic material, recovery of minerals and wastewater treatment process. Few other studies reported that various reactive metal oxides and complex minerals can be easily recovered from red mud using improved approach of alkali roasting and leaching [27]. Industrial use of red mud in absorption applications such as removal of hydrogen sulfide from hot gases and extraction of rare earth materials from ores have been extensively studied for commercial applications [28]. The composition of red mud is quite heterogeneous containing major quantity of Fe as an element. Red mud composition largely depends upon the types of bauxite material (ore) and chemical processes used for the production of alumina. General composition of red mud shows presence of Fe2O3, Al2O3, SiO2, Na2O, TiO2, CaO, MgO along with few other constituents such as K, V, Cr, Mn, P, Ga, Mg, Zn, Nb, Th, and Ni, dispersed in smaller quantities. X-ray analysis of the material indicate presence of α ̶ Fe2O3 (hematite), gibbsite (Al(OH3)), quartz (SiO2), calcite (CaCO3), calcium silicate (Ca2(SiO4)), sodium aluminate (NaAlO2) and sodalite (Na8Al6(SiO4).6Cl2). In addition, goethite (FeOOH), magnetite (Fe3O4), iron hydroxide (Fe(OH3)), anatase (TiO2), halloysite (Al2Si2O5(OH)4), bayerite (Al(OH3)), bohemite (AlO(OH), diaspore (AlO(OH) and kaolinite (Al2Si2O5(OH)4) phases are also found as constituents in red mud [25]. The observed color of red mud is principally attributed to the presence of hematite (α–Fe2O3) component in the material. Current global production of red mud nearly exceed 90 MMT (million metric tons), therefore, requires proactive step to find its diversified commercial utilities [26]. Recent use of red-mud based catalyst for sustainable energy production shows promising applications through different processes such as characterization, activation and stability studies along with mechanistic aspects [28]. In this aspect, potential utilizations of red-mud for valuable metal recovery, alternative catalyst for diverse processes such as hydrodechlorination, hydrogenation and hydrocarbon oxidation can be considered in view of future commercial importance [29–34]. Therefore, the strategy for direct use of red mud can be explored keeping in view the presence of residual metal ions in the matrix which can facilitate transforming the material to a functional material. Our research work is objectively focused on impregnation of copper (in the form of copper oxide) to prepare copper supported on red-mud as a catalyst that can be used efficiently for hydroxylation of benzene. Copper is a transition metal with variable oxidation states. Supported copper catalyst found applications for various organic transformation reactions, such as reduction of nitro-group, oxidation of CO, etc. [28,34]. Literature studies indicate that combination of copper and iron (present in red mud) can facilitate activation of CH bond in benzene for selective introduction of oxygen in hydroxylation of benzene [10]. The prepared materials is expected to show good catalytic behavior attributed to availability of active sites on the material surface as well as overall stability of the material due to influence of support. Further, in present investigation, the catalyst copper oxide supported on activated red-mud was prepared using environment friendly procedure. All prepared materials were characterized and tested under optimized conditions for hydroxylation of benzene to phenol with variation of parameters. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Copper nitrate trihydrate [Cu(NO)3.3H2O], H2O2 (50 w/w % in water), cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB), ammonium hydroxide (NH4OH), benzene (C6H6, purity>99 %) and acetonitrile (HPCL grade) were procured from Sigma Aldrich, India. All chemicals were used without further purifications. Red-mud was obtained from HINDALCO, India, as a gift sample and designated as RM. ICP-AES analysis of collected sample material shows that RM contain nearly 75 % of Fe as an element. In addition, analysis results shows presence of few other elements such as Ti (3.64 %), Si (18.76 %), Al (6.18 %), Na (5.90 %) and Ca (0.54 %). Distilled water (DW) was used in experiments for dilution of stock solutions and for preparation of various aqueous solutions of chemicals/reagents. 2.2 Preparation of activated red mud (ARM) Activated red-mud was prepared using protocols adopted from literature survey with some modifications [25,26]. Following typical procedure, 2.0 g of RM was taken in a 100 mL clean beaker and added with 60 mL of distilled water. The whole mixture was stirred for 1 h to ensure proper dispersion of solid materials in solvent. The dispersed solid materials was added with 10.0 mL of 6 M HCl in a drop-wise manner and the stirring of whole mixture was continued for further 1 h time duration. Subsequently, NH4OH (28–30 % v/v) was also added in a drop-wise manner that resulted in formation of a black colored precipitated material. The precipitated solid was autoclaved at 180 °C for 24 h. In subsequent step, the material was washed repeatedly with distilled water to ensure neutral pH (i.e., pH = 7.0) of the washing solution. It is to be noted that repeated washing of the material facilitates removal of excess sodium and calcium. The final product material was dried at 120 °C for 24 h and subsequently thoroughly grinded (using mortar and pestle) to fine particle/powdered form. The finely particulate material was further calcined at elevated temperature of 800 °C for 6 h and stored as activated red mud (ARM) material. 2.3 Preparation of doubly activated red mud (AARM) Doubly activated red mud (AARM) was prepared using ARM material. Powdered ARM sample material was dispersed in 60 mL of DW taken in a 100 mL beaker and the mixture was stirred for 1 h to ensure proper dispersion of solid materials in water. In a subsequent step, 1.8 g of surfactant (CTAB), dissolved in 3.5 mL of DW, was added in a drop-wise manner to the above mixture under continuous stirring condition for 1 h followed by slow addition of NH4OH (28–30% v/v). The precipitated materials were allowed to remain in continuous stirring condition for 2 h, subsequently autoclaved at 180 °C for 24 h. The autoclaved material was washed repeatedly with DW to ensure neutral pH (pH = 7.0) of the washing solution. The filtered solid material was dried at 120 °C for 24 h, grinded thoroughly; subsequently calcined at 800 °C to produce doubly activated red mud (AARM) ready for further use. 2.4 Preparation of catalyst (CuO_AARM) The catalyst (CuO_AARM) is prepared using following procedure: 1.8 g of finely powdered AARM was dispersed in 60 mL of water (denoted as mixture A) using a 250 mL beaker. In a separate 100 mL beaker, 0.455 g of Cu(NO3)2.3H2O was dissolved in 10 mL of DW. Further, 0.343 g CTAB was dissolved in 3.0 mL of water using a small conical flask. The CTAB solution was added drop-wise to the metal solution of Cu(NO3)2.3H2O and the mixture was denoted as mixture B. In subsequent step, mixture B was added to mixture A under continuous stirring condition over a time period of 1 h and subsequently autoclaved at 180 °C for 24 h. The autoclaved sample was cooled to room temperature, washed with DW, further dried and calcined at 550 °C for 6 h to produce CuO_AARM catalyst material. The material was stored in a sealed bottle flushed with nitrogen gas, ready for further use. 2.5 Analytical measurements The analytical measurements and the characterization of catalyst materials were done using following instruments: Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of the materials were obtained using Bruker D8 advance X-ray diffractometer fitted with a Lynex eye high-speed strip detector and Cu–Kα radiation source. Diffraction patterns were recorded @ 0.5° per minute within 2θ range of 5 – 80°. Transmission electron micrograph (TEM) of sample materials were recorded using JEOL JEM-2100 microscope. For this, samples were prepared by dispersing materials in ethanol mounted on a lacey carbon Formvar coated nickel grid. Inductively Coupled Plasma–Atomic Emission Spectroscopic (ICP–AES) analysis was carried out using Spectrometer model: PS 3000 UV(DRE), Leeman Labs, Inc. (USA). Similarly, both thermo-gravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential thermal analysis (DTA) of sample materials were carried out using Thermo-gravimetric Analyzer TGA 8000 (Perkin Elmer instruments). In this case, 2.15 mg of material was used with following conditions i.e, heating rate of 5 °C min–1 in oxygen environment. The FTIR spectrum was recorded on a Thermo Nicolet 8700 (USA) instrument with resolutions of 4.0 cm–1, scan rate of 36 cm̶ 1, frequency range of 4000–400 cm–1 and at operating temperature of 23–25 °C. All spectrum results were checked for their reproducibility. Conversion and selectivity to reaction was determined using gas chromatography (GC, Agilent 7890B, column DB–WAX (30 m ×0.53 mm ×1 μm) fitted with a FID (flame ionization detector). Temperature Programmed Reduction (TPR) studies were carried out using Chemiosorption Analyser (Autochem II 2920 Micromeritics Instrument Corp., USA). Surface area analysis was done using Micromeritics ASAP 2020 Surface Area and Porosity Analyser instrument. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was done using Thermo Fischer Scientific ESCALAB Xi+. 2.6 Hydroxylation of benzene The oxidation of benzene was carried out using two necked round bottom (RB) flask of 50 mL fitted with a water-condenser. Using the RB, benzene (0.5 g) was added with 10 mL of acetonitrile solvent. The mixture was stirred for 15 min at 40 °C and aliquot of reaction mixture was taken immediately for analysis in GC (counted as 0 h for reference). Subsequently, 0.05 g of CuO_AARM (catalyst material) was added to the reaction mixture in RB and stirred for 5 min to ensure uniform distribution of particles. In a next step, 1 mL (2.5 mol L–1) of H2O2 (50 % v/v) was added drop-wise to initiate the oxidation process. The temperature was gradually raised (with an increment of 15–20 °C per 15 min time interval) to 75 °C (±1 °C). The whole reaction mixture was continuously stirred at 75 °C for 24 h. Aliquot of reaction mixture was withdrawn at every 2 h time interval, centrifuged and injected externally in GC–FID to monitor the progress of the reaction. The monitoring and analysis of aliquot of sample reaction mixture was continued until conversion and selectivity shows constant result. Progress of the reaction shows consistent result in 24 h and blank experiment was also performed in similar manner without the presence of CuO_AARM in the reaction flask. For blank reaction, the amount of conversion, calculated from standard calibration curve in GC, was found to be quite negligible and hence considered as zero conversion for calculative purpose. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization 3.1.1 X-ray diffraction analysis The X-Ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of RM, AARM and CuO_AARM is presented in Fig. 1 . RM shows peaks related to presence of multiple phases i.e., presence of hematite (Fe2O3, JCPDS card no: 89-0599), magnetite (Fe3O4,JCPDS card no: 89-4319), rutile (TiO2, JCPDS card no: 89-4921),Ti2O3 (JCPDS card no:89-746), gibbsite (Al(OH)3, (JCPDS card no.02−0249) cancrinite (Na6CaAl6Si6CO3), corundum (Al2O3, JCPDS card no: 89-3072), calcite (CaCO3) (JCPDS card no. 86-2340), and sodium silicate (NaSiO3) (JCPDS card no.16-0815) [35–37]. AARM, on the other hand, shows disappearance of peaks related to presence of cancrinite, calcite and sodium silicate. This indicates complete removal of oxides of sodium and calcium from sample materials during activation process. It was also observed that peaks related to hematite, magnetite and corundum were much prominent in nature indicating presence of iron and aluminum oxides as the major components in support material. The diffraction pattern of CuO_AARM shows additional peaks of CuO at 2θ of 35.55°, 38.74°, 48.70°, 58.30°, 68.14° and 75.28° (JCPDS card no: 89-5898). 3.1.2 FTIR analysis The FTIR spectrum of sample materials RM, AARM, and CuO_AARM is presented in Fig. 2 . RM shows one broad peak in the range 3200–3600 cm–1 attributed to ν(OH)str indicating presence of hydroxyl group and/or presence of bound water /solvent molecules in the material. Further, peak at 1635 cm–1 attributed to bending vibration, δ(O–H), of hydroxyl group. Presence of peaks at 1450 cm–1 is attributed to ν(CO)str and peak at 998 cm–1 is attributed to presence of ν(Si–O)str vibrational band in the material, thus confirming the presence of both carbonate and silicate groups [36]. Spectral analysis also shows presence of both Fe – O (peak at 577 and 694 cm–1) and Al – O (peak at 474 and 638 cm–1) in RM. Both AARM and CuO_AARM, show peak at 1450 cm̶1, assigned to ν(CO)str, with much diminishing intensity indicating successful leaching of carbonates during the activation process. In addition, appearance of a new peak at 801 cm–1, in case of AARM, attributed to possible phase change (Al(OH)3 to γ-Al2O3) during the activation process [36–38]. In case of CuO_AARM material, the intensity of both ν(OH)str and δ(O – H) shows enhancement which could be due to the absorption of water molecule by crystalline/nano-crystalline CuO formed upon the surface of the support material. Loading of CuO, the active phase, is confirmed from increase in intensity of peak at 577 cm–1 [38]. 3.1.3 TG–DTA analysis Thermo-gravimetric analysis (TGA) – Differential Thermal Analysis (DTA) is important tool for study of material stability with respect to application of temperature. The thermal characteristics of CuO_AARM was evaluated using TGA–DTA technique. The thermogram of uncalcined catalyst material is presented in Fig.3 . The thermogram, in a temperature range of 30–550 °C, shows weight loss of 19.7 %. The initial weight loss (∼1.69 %) in the material happens within a temperature range of 30–210 °C. Correspondingly, presence of broad endotherm, in differential thermal analysis (DTA), attributed to elimination of surface adsorbed water molecules. The weight loss (∼17.7 %) within a temperature range of 210–550 °C, accompanied by multiple DTA peaks observed at 226.49 °C, 285.85 °C, 328.08 °C and 455.38 °C, was attributed to conversion of goethite (FeOOH), gibbsite (Al(OH)3), boehmite (AlO(OH)) to Fe2O3, Fe3O4 and alumina (Al2O3), respectively [36]. Weight loss within the temperature range 250–350 °C was attributed to decomposition of CTAB molecules [9]. No further weight loss was observed beyond 550 °C indicating formation of stable and crystalline CuO_AARM material. Moreover, no weight loss was also observed in the temperature range of 606 −712 °C and 742–898 °C indicating that calcite and sodium aluminum carbonate silicate, originally present in RM material, were no longer present in the activated material (AARM) impregnated with CuO [28]. The thermogram of RM and AARM is also furnished in Fig.S1† (supporting information) for reference. The obtained result shows good correlation with X-Ray diffractogram analysis [28,36]. 3.1.4 H2-TPR analysis The reduction properties of the synthesized catalyst was investigated by hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) analysis and compared with that of CuO loaded commercial Fe2O3 i.e., CuO_Comm.Fe2O3. Fig. 4 shows the reduction profile of both CuO_AARM and CuO_Comm.Fe2O3. The TPR profile of CuO_AARM shows multiple reduction peaks α, β and γ at 243 °C, 425 °C and 700 °C, respectively. The 1st peak (α) at 243 °C is attributed to reduction of Cu2+ to Cu° while the 2nd peak (β) at 425 °C corresponds to the reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4. The broad peak in the range 600–800 °C (γ) shows two step reduction of Fe3O4, i.e., Fe3O4→FeO→Fe [36]. In case of CuO_Comm. Fe2O3, similar kind of reduction peaks were also observed. The intensity of CuO reduction peak is found to be much prominent in case of CuO_AARM in comparison to CuO_Comm.Fe2O3 sample material. All these results clearly indicate that the synthesized catalyst is easily reducible at low temperature which could be attributed to presence of highly scattered and small sized CuO species impregnated upon the support AARM material [38]. 3.1.5 BET surface area analysis Surface area analysis is one of the most important parameter for solid catalytic material. The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms (supporting information Fig.S2†) and corresponding pore size distribution curves of RM, AARM and CuO-AARM materials is presented in Fig. 5 . The surface area and total pore volume of the RM was found to be 5.69 m2 g–1 and 0.014 cm3 g–1, respectively. The activated material, AARM, shows enhancement of both surface area and pore volume to 28.67 m2 g–1 and 0.080 cm3 g–1, respectively. Leaching of calcium and sodium contents during acid treatment could be attributed to such an observation. CuO_AARM shows further enhancement of both surface area and pore volume to 58.50 m2 g–1 and 0.163 cm3 g–1, respectively, indicating loading of active metal CuO in AARM support material [35,36]. Further, the increment in surface area and pore volume of the catalytic material could facilitate higher conversion as well as efficiency of the reaction process [36]. The pore sizes of RM, AARM and CuO_AARM were found to be within the range of 10–12 nm indicating meso-porous characteristics of all prepared materials. Noticeably, the meso-porosity of the prepared catalyst was well maintained even after the acid treatment and calcination processes suggesting higher thermal stabilities of materials under consideration. The energy dispersive x-ray (EDAX) analysis indicates the elemental compositions which also corroborated with results obtained from X-Ray diffractogram studies (Fig.S3–S5)† (supporting information). Fig. 7 shows the XPS patterns of unused (fresh) and used (spent) catalytic materials. Analysis was done for Fe (2p), Ti (2p), Al (2 s), Si (2 s) and Cu (2p) regions. The catalyst contain iron oxide (both Fe2O3 and Fe3O4), presence of which is supported from deconvulation pattern of Fe (2p3/2): Fe2+ (710.8 eV), Fe3+ (713.3 eV); and Fe (2p1/2): Fe2+ (723.7 eV) and Fe3+ (726.8 eV), thus confirming the observation. In addition, presence of satellite peaks at 716.3 and 719.7 and 730.8 and 734.3 eV supported the evidence of presence of mixed Fe2O3 and Fe3O4 in the catalyst sample material [39,40]. The result shows the binding energies of Fe2+/Fe3+ = 0.7∼0.5 eV, Fe3+ (Fe2p3/2)–Fe3+ (Fe 2p1/2) = 13.6∼14, Fe2+(Fe 2p3/2)–Fe2+ (Fe 2p1/2) = 13.8∼14, and (Fe2p3/2)/(Fe2p1/2) = 1.8∼2 eV which is in close agreement with literature cited values [19–21]. It is also observed that the intensity of Fe2+ is relatively intense in comparison to Fe3+ (in case of fresh catalyst); whereas, spent catalyst shows relatively less intense Fe2+ peak attributed to redox reactions at the surface. Analysis of Ti (2p) core level shows binding energies at 458.2 and 464.2 eV which confirms the presence of Ti4+ and minor presence Ti3+ [22]. Presence of satellite peak at 471.7 eV confirms the presence of mixed oxide of TiO2 and Ti2O3 and the difference in binding energies between Ti4+(Ti 2p3/2) – Ti4+ (Ti 2p1/2) = 5.9 ∼ 5.7 eV further supports the evidence of presence of mixed Ti (Ti4+ and Ti3+) in supported material [22,41–45]. In case of analysis of used catalyst, the corresponding O1s XPS shows extra deconvulated peak at 533.8 eV which is related to presence of CO bond [46]. No such deviation was noticed in case of used catalysts. 3.2 Studies of catalytic activities Catalytic performance of the material was evaluated using variation of number of parameters such as reaction temperature, time, amount of oxidant, solvent and amount of catalytic material [48]. The effect of temperature upon the progress of reaction (i.e., conversion/selectivity) was studied at 60, 75 and 100 °C. It was observed that at 60 °C temperature (supporting information Fig.S9†), the conversion of benzene to phenol remains almost 54.6 %; whereas, the selectivity was found to be 57.0 %. On the other hand, catechol formation was restricted to 49.0 % only. Reaction carried out at 75 °C, in Fig.8 , shows higher selectivity (i.e., 84.5 %) for phenol with percentage of conversion enhanced to 87.1 %. Reaction carried out at 100.0 °C (supporting information Fig.S10†) shows formation of more quantity of catechol. Analysis of these results indicate that the rate of decomposition of H2O2 on the surface of catalyst could be slower at 60 °C. Decomposition of H2O2 produces hydroxyl radical species that initiate the hydroxylation reaction to form phenol as well as catechol. The reduction in conversion as well as selectivity of phenol at 60 °C could be attributed to slow decomposition of H2O2 [24,48]. Reaction carried out at elevated temperature (i.e., 100 °C) indicate that H2O2 molecules get decomposed abruptly on the surface of the catalytic material (CuO_AARM) providing enough hydroxyl radical species to initiate the conversion process. Hence, phenol could get over-oxidized to form catechol while passing through a transition state. It is to be noted that at 100 °C, over-oxidation of phenol (to form catechol) provide less selectivity for the formation of phenol. It was also observed that reaction carried out at 75 °C produce optimum amount of phenol with appreciable selectivity, i.e., the amount of conversion of phenol increases from 30.4 % to 87.1 % within a time span of 24 h and the selectivity to phenol formation also enhanced to 84.5 %. Fig. 9 . shows the variation of amount of oxidant H2O2 in a range of 1.0 ̶ 2.5 mol L–1. Graphical result indicates that initially phenol is formed with 96.0 % selectivity at 1.0 mol L–1 H2O2 concentration and gradually phenol selectivity reaches 84.5 % when concentration of H2O2 enhanced to 2.5 mol L–1. Overall conversion of benzene to phenol is found to be 87.1 %. Analysis of results indicate that at low oxidant concentration, amount of H2O2 availability to provide necessary free radical species (to carry out the reaction) remains low. Hence, it could be possible that the hydroxyl species (formed upon the surface of catalytic material) favor selective formation of phenol only. Increment in oxidant concentration facilitate forward reaction (i.e, hydroxylation of benzene) and product selectivity also favor formation phenol. The obtained result also indicates that an optimized amount of oxidant is necessary for achieving good selectivity to the formation of desired product molecule. The effect of variation of solvent upon the progress of the reaction was also studied using acetone, water, acetonitrile and mixture of water and acetonitrile (1:1) and result of progress of the reaction is furnished in Table S2† (supporting information). It was observed that selectivity of phenol remained almost same in all chosen solvents, but conversion (%) was enhanced in acetonitrile solvent only which is attributed to good miscibility factor for acetonitrile that could favor formation of phenol at an optimum temperature and oxidant concentration. In order to draw a comparative aspects, a set of experiments were run where CuO_AARM along with RM, AARM and CuO_Comm.Fe2O3 materials were also used under optimized conditions. Acetonitrile was used as chosen a solvent and benzene was used as a substrate. Experiment was also was also carried out in absence of catalytic material (denoted as Blank). The reaction mixture temperature was maintained at 75 °C and amount of product formation were analyzed only after 24 h to ensure a good result. No evidence of product formation was obtained in absence of catalytic material. When the reaction was carried out in presence of RM and the progress of reaction was monitored (using GC), the result indicated a very low amount of conversion (∼2%) of substrate to product molecules. Using a new experimental set up, AARM was used directly along with benzene as substrate and H2O2 as an oxidant. The progress of the reaction indicated only 4% of conversion of benzene to phenol. On the other hand, use of CuO_AARM with benzene as substrate and H2O2 as oxidant indicated 87.1 % conversion of benzene to phenol with 84.5 % selectivity towards formation of phenol. Catechol was also formed with 15.5 % selectivity. The experiments were re-run in presence as well as in absence of H2O2 oxidant material. Interestingly, it was observed that reaction carried out in absence of H2O2 initialized very slowly and apparently resulted in almost no quantifiable conversion. Experiment with CuO_Comm.Fe2O3 showed 24.5 % of conversion with 69.2 % selectivity towards phenol. We also synthesized nano CuO, nano Fe2O3 and nano Fe3O4 (as control experiment) using hydrothermal technique and the result indicated low conversion as well as selectivity. As indicated in Fig. 8, the effect of contact time with catalyst for hydroxylation of benzene was studied at 75 °C, where in 24 h of equilibrium time period, the reaction proceeded with a selectivity of 84.5 % and conversion efficiency of 87.1 %. The amount of conversion per unit mass of catalytic material at equilibrium and at time ‘t’ is calculated using the equation: (1) qe = (Co – Ce) ×V/M and (2) qt = (Co – Ct) ×V/M Where, qe = amount per unit mass (mg/g) of catalytic material at equilibrium; qt = amount of per unit mass (mg g–1) of catalytic material at time ‘t’; Co = initial concentration of reactant (mol L–1); Ce = concentration of reactant at equilibrium (mol L–1); Ct = concentration (mol L–1) of reactant at time ‘t’; ‘V’ is the volume of the reactant in mL and ‘M’ is the mass (g) of the catalyst. Thus, the order of the reaction can be evaluated using following empirical equation [40]: (3) ln ( q e - q t ) = ln q e - k 1 t where, k1 = rate constant and the value of k1 can be determined from slope of linear plot of the equation. From the data plot, as indicated in Fig.10 , the linearity of graph establishes the fact that the reaction follows a pseudo 1st order kinetics. Further, the activation energies (Ea) were calculated using Arrhenius plot (in Fig.S11†; supporting information). The values of rate constant and activation energies are furnished in Table S3† (supporting information). Activation energy (Ea ), calculated at different temperature indicate that the oxidation rate does not affect the reactivity of catalyst and the results quantitatively shows monomolecular decomposition of transition complex which is formed during the reaction process. Activation energy represents the energy difference between activated complex and the reactant molecules. CuO_AARM catalytic material contains CuO and other metal oxides of support material. Copper act as the active metal that facilitates the surface reactions. Initial decomposition of H2O2 happens in presence iron to form reactive oxygen species such as hydroperoxides, superoxides and peroxides [26,27] and the dissociation pathway is furnished as scheme-S1(†) (supporting information). Taking into account above discussions and literature studies, a proposed reaction mechanism is furnished in Scheme 1 which shows the conversion of benzene to phenol in presence of AARM_CuO catalyst in various steps. In step-1, benzene forms benzene-radical cation (C6H6 + ) in presence of CuO that results in the reduction of Cu2+ to Cu+; In step-2, H2O2 undergoes rapid decomposition in presence of Fe2+ to generate active OH radical and OH– (hydroxyl) species through Fe2+/H2O2 (Fenton-like reaction) [49,50] (Eq.4) where Fe2+ gets oxidize to Fe3+; In step-3, the hydroxylation of benzene by OH (radical) produces an intermediate hydroxyl-cylohexadienyl radicals that undergoes self-destruction to yield phenol by releasing H+ ion and electron. The released electron (e–) species is captured by catalyst to reduce Fe3+ back into Fe2+ while the liberated H+ ion reacts with OH– species (produced during H2O2 decomposition) to form undissociated H2O molecules. Meanwhile, in presence of H2O2, the generated Cu+ and Fe3+ can be converted back into Cu2+ and Fe2+ (Eqs. 5 and 6) that can again participate in the reaction. Herein, the reversible Fe2+/Fe3+ and Cu2+/Cu+ reactions play a vital role in the oxidation of benzene to phenol. Thus, it can be concluded that, the synergy between the active CuO NPs and AARM support material (consistent with TPR analysis) provides a suitable catalytic platform for the effective hydroxylation of benzene to yield phenol where the small-sized dispersed CuO provides easily accessible catalytic surface and AARM supports the formation of phenol [51], represented as follows: (4) Fe2+ +H2O2 → Fe3+ + OH + OH– (5) Fe3+ +H2O2 → Fe2+ + OOH + H+ (6) Cu+ +H2O2 → Cu2+ + OH + OH– Several methods have been developed to detect hydroxyl radicals. Detection and hence quenching of hydroxyl radicals has been carried out to validate the participation of hydroxyl radicals in the proposed reaction (supporting information, Hydroxyl radicals quenching S1†) [52]. While it is understood that CuO_AARM shows good kinetic control over the decomposition of the H2O2 on the surface of the catalyst, the cooperative effect of presence of few other metals such as Ti4+ and Al3+, in addition to both Cu2+ and Fe, also remain as contributing factors for overall conversion and selectivity towards direct hydroxylation of the benzene to form phenol. This is supported by the evidence that conversion and selectivity in a solid catalytic material is mostly a structure dependent property. The presence of strong acidic centers (such as Al3+) in catalytic frame-work structure could also limit the reaction to some extent (i.e., lowering the amount of conversion) while accelerating the H2O2 decomposition during the hydroxylation process involving H2O2 [53]. Incorporation of CuO in AARM support material favors activation of both oxygen and CH bond which is immensely important for catalyst activity, selectivity and stability [48]. Few other studies also reported that use of H2O2 in appropriate molar ratio that can be helpful in enhancing the selectivity and hence conversion [4]. 3.4 Catalyst reusable properties Reusability and stability are two most important features for industrial/practical applications of catalytic materials. Hence, reusability of CuO_AARM was examined using batch process. Fig.11 graphically demonstrate that the catalyst is effective up to five continuous cycles of operations. The catalyst was recovered by filtration after completion of 1st cycle of operation and washed with acetone for 4–5 times and dried at 60 °C overnight for next cycle of study. The same process was continued for 4 consecutive cycles. It is shown that conversion as well as selectivity remains practically unchanged up to 5th cycles of operation. Percentage of conversion was found to be 86.7 % and the selectivity was found to be 83.9 % after completion of 5th cycle of studies. The catalyst shows no apparent loss of properties in terms of selectivity and amount of conversion. Interestingly, repeated use of catalyst up to 5th cycle of operation shows no agglomeration of particles and no further change in particle size distribution projecting the material for future potential applications. 4 Conclusions In present work, we demonstrated a new nano structured copper oxide supported on acid activated red mud as catalyst for efficient conversion of benzene to phenol in presence of H2O2 oxidant. The catalyst was characterized by various advanced instrumentation techniques. The X-ray diffraction pattern of the material shows presence of iron and aluminum as the major components in the support material in addition to evidence of effective loading of copper as active metal. The H2-TPR profile indicate the easy reducible characteristic of material at low temperature. The meso-porous characteristics as well as higher thermal stabilities of materials were established showing material’s suitability for diverse applications. The XPS patterns of both unused and used catalytic materials show presence of Fe (as Fe2O3 and Fe3O4) and Cu in addition to Ti, Al, and Si and the electronic properties of the material remain unchanged after repeated used indicating the contribution of these elements in overall catalytic activities. The catalytic activities shows optimum result at 75 °C where the hydroxylation reaction proceeds with selectivity of 84.5 % and conversion efficiency of 87.1 % within 24 h. Reaction kinetics found to follow pseudo 1st order while the mechanistic aspects, shows a good kinetic control over the decomposition of the H2O2 on the surface of the catalyst. More importantly, the reusability of the catalyst indicate good conversion efficiency and selectivity (86.7 % and 83.9 %, respectively) even after completion of 5th consecutive cycles of operation in batch mode. Additionally, the catalyst shows minimal loss of elements such as Fe and Cu during various stages of synthesis process (supporting information Table S4†) signifying materials core characteristics. While the technical and scientific aspects of the work clearly emphasizes upon effective use of red mud as a support for preparation of new catalytic material, the result of reduction of steps for hydroxylation process add new dimension of catalyst application in an efficient manner. A comparative aspects of CuO_AARM vis-a-vis newly developed/reported commercial catalysts indicates better opportunity for CuO_AARM in terms of conversion and selectivity (supporting information Table-S5†) [51,54–67]. In view of above facts, CuO_AARM could be projected as suitable alternative catalytic material for hydroxylation of benzene for potential commercial and industrial applications with environment friendly aspects. coredata.dc:description: Phenol is a key intermediate in chemical industry. The present research work reports facile synthesis of a new copper supported activated red mud as a heterogeneous catalyst for oxidative conversion of benzene to phenol. The process is simple and efficient for one pot hydroxylation reaction using H2O2 as an oxidant. The catalyst was characterized using FTIR, XRD, TEM, XPS and BET surface area analyzer. Catalyst reducible properties were studied using H2-TPR technique. The one-pot hydroxylation reaction, carried out at 75 °C under optimum reaction conditions in presence of catalytic material, shows conversion of benzene to phenol with 84.5 % and 87.1 % selectivity and conversion efficiency, respectively. The proposed mechanism emphasizes upon cooperative effect of residual and embedded metal ions in solid catalyst matrix as the contributing factor for efficient conversion and selectivity. The reusable properties of the material, tested up to 5th consecutive cycles of batch operation, indicate retention of selectivity (83.9 %) as well as conversion efficiency (86.7 %), suitable for future commercial development adhering to the principle of green chemistry.
coredata.dc:title: Heterogeneous recyclable copper oxide supported on activated red mud as an efficient and stable catalyst for the one pot hydroxylation of benzene to phenol
